text: Sea Troll Hags are thankfully only rarely encountered outside their deep sea habitats. They wield the foul magic of the deep oceans against those who draw their ire.
Goblin Big Bosses of the Carrion Tribes are survivors, they are either clever enough to manipulate their rather dim troll overlords or just faster than their peers when running away.

These trolls are more than willing to throw their enemies a bone or two.

Wandering goblins can sometimes be found trailing Troll tribes in hope of picking clean any discarded carcasses. Ugma pressed these gobbos into service and they make for good scouts and archers keeping scavengers away.

The Goblins of the Carrion Tribe are largely ignored by the Trolls as long as they find enough food, something the squig hoppers have no difficulty in.  At any rate it's a much better deal than you'd get under an orc.
The number of goblins under Ugma's service grew so large he ordained them as the Carrion Tribe, with a new sense of belonging these outcasts gladly make up the chaff for Ugma's armies

These terrifying creatures are similar in appearance to their kin the Stone Trolls but of a much darker complexion. They are attributed in myth to utter a deep guttural sound, akin to mocking laughter before they tear their prey to pieces."
Only under the influence of a powerful warrior will the mighty ice trolls of Norsca accept armour pieces on their bodies.
Not unlike humans, trolls that live further away from the influence of chaos tend to be smaller and less impressive than their northern brethren.
The strongest, biggest and most ferocious angry ice trolls you could find. After countless battles, the frozen blood of their enemies on their bodies gave them their red hue.
Cavern Trolls are a subspecies of River Trolls who usually dwell in underground lakes and seas. They prey on the horrors of the deep and the occasional adventurer or Dwarf miner.

Whether these trolls were originally normal Stone Trolls or maybe another Troll species entirely is unknown, but their skin has been hardened to a point that they barely receive damage and rarely feel any pain. If they are hurt though, their confidence is shaken easily.
Living in the polluted of Marienburg's sewers near the sea, these Cavern Trolls learned how to smash ships for food.
There is only one troll in existence that can really be called a leader.  Luckily a mix of mind control and savage punishment can produce trolls that can at least create the illusion of leadership.
These Trolls got named by surviving Kislevite soldiers because they have often been seen together with the Trollking.
Trolls that have somewhat adapted to the forest life. They are difficult to spot in forests when standing still, but at the same time simply don't comprehend the concept of sneaking.
Bile Trolls are descendants of a troll horde that once defeated and devoured a Nurgle Army. Infected by the Plaguefather's many gifts, they suffer horribly for it.
Snow Trolls live on the highest peaks of mountains covered in eternal ice. They are of enormous size, dwelling in icy caves which are covered with the bones of their victims.
Born in the fallen Karak Azgal, chief Ugma is an unusually intelligent river troll leader. He himself suspects that his intellect increased through prolonged contact with warpstone.

Lava Trolls are an oddity, originally hailing from the Dark Lands. It is unknown if they are a testament of the incredible adaptability of trolls to every environment or the result of a twisted experiment by the sinister inhabitants of these accursed lands.

Rumored to be either creations of Chaos or escaped Moulder experiments, the Warped Ones are growing warpstone from their body, appearently without suffering ill effects from it. They are seemingly immune to pain and will only run near death.

Rarely can the elusive Shugon - Trolls of the Sea - be lured to leave their deep sea habitats and venture on land. The enormous pressure of the deep sea give them monstrous strength, even compared to other trolls.
The existance of Troll champions can be seen as a proof for the humor of the dark gods or their cruelty. Or both.
Sometimes, rarely, a seemingly normal troll never stops to grow. Scholars still debate possible reasons, but it is probably connected to the volatile, chaotic nature of troll biology.
